JUDGES: Ganna Yudkivska;Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented before ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON , of ORG .
CARDINAL . NORP The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . In DATE , shortly after the establishment in GPE of the communist regime , the applicant was administratively detained in a labour camp for a period of DATE . The order for his detention ( no . CARDINAL ) , issued by the Director of ORG of ORG on an unknown date in DATE , read as follows :

“ Bearing in mind that the regional head of ORG in GPE has reported , in letter no . DATE , that [ the applicant ] , who is DATE and lives in GPE , rapes women by threatening them with murder [ and ] talks openly against ORG , I order that he be placed in a labour camp ... for a period of DATE . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the order was sent to the GPE militia for enforcement . The applicant was arrested on DATE and sent to a labour camp DATE after that . He was released from there on DATE .

CARDINAL . In DATE , after the communist regime had come to an end , the legislature enacted the Political and Civic Rehabilitation of Persecuted Individuals Act ( “ the DATE LAW ) , granting certain rights to compensation to individuals who had been subjected to repression during the regime ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . As the applicant wished to avail himself of the opportunities created by the LAW , he asked ORG to issue him a certificate concerning his detention . He intended to use it as proof that he had been subjected to repression within the meaning of the LAW and was thus entitled to compensation . On DATE the ORG issued a certificate which said that the applicant had been detained “ for criminal reasons ” on the basis of “ order no . CARDINAL ” . On an objection by the applicant , the competent services of the Ministry carried out a second check . In a letter of DATE they informed the applicant that he had been detained “ without a conviction or sentence , on the basis of order no . CARDINAL of ORG , for ‘ the rape of a girl’ ” , and that the Ministry did not have any other information on file concerning the repression against him . The letter further advised the applicant that , if unsatisfied by that reply , he could clear his name through the courts .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant brought proceedings against ORG and ORG of the Interior , seeking a declaration that his detention in DATE had been repression due to his origin and political views . On DATE ORG ( PERSON районен съд ) allowed his claim and found it established that he had been detained because of his origin and political views . On an appeal by ORG of the Interior , on DATE ORG ( Пловдивски окръжен съд ) set that decision aside , holding that the applicant was trying to establish a legally relevant fact , which , according to LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , was possible only if specifically provided by law , which was not the case . The applicant could instead assert his rights under section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The applicant ’s ensuing appeal was rejected by ORG ( NORP съд ) on DATE ( опр. № CARDINAL от DATE г. по д. № DATE г. , ORG , GPE г. о. ) . The court noted that neither the DATE Act nor any other statute made provision for the judicial establishment of the fact of repression , as required under LAW DATE Code . That was indeed a legally relevant fact , but it could be established in special administrative proceedings .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant again asked ORG to issue him a certificate concerning his detention . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE the ORG ’s archive department informed him that , according to their records , the reasons why the authorities had ordered his detention in DATE were that he had been “ rap[ing ] women by threatening them with murder [ and ] talk[ing ] openly against the Fatherland Front ” .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant once again brought proceedings against ORG and ORG of the Interior , seeking declarations ( a ) that the order for his detention was incorrect inasmuch as it relied on criminal grounds and ( b ) that the official of ORG who had drawn up the order had recorded a false statement of fact in order to provide justification for the detention . In a bench ruling of CARDINAL DATE the ORG discontinued the examination of the second claim , holding that a ruling that an official of ORG had made a false document would not protect the applicant ’s right to good reputation and honour . The first claim , which aimed to establish that the order had been incorrect , also made it superfluous to make findings in respect of the individual who had drawn it up . The applicant did not appeal against that ruling .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG discontinued the proceedings , finding that the applicant ’s first claim was inadmissible as well . It held , by reference to the established caselaw of ORG under LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , that the existence of a concrete legal interest in pursuing the claim was a mandatory prerequisite for its examination . Therefore , the applicant had to show that a judicial declaration that the detention order was incorrect would have an impact on his relations with the defendant and that there was no other procedure to establish such incorrectness . The order had not been a document purporting to certify the reasons for which the applicant had been detained or to establish that the events it mentioned – “ rapes women by threatening them with murder ” – had indeed occurred , but to compel the applicant to endure a sanction . Therefore , the only thing that it proved was that the applicant had been detained on such grounds . The applicant ’s criminal record , which was the only legal means of establishing conviction for criminal conduct , was clean . There was therefore no dispute between the applicant and the defendants about whether he had engaged in criminal conduct . In so far as the applicant claimed that the content of the detention order had prevented him from obtaining compensation under LAW , he could have recourse to the special procedure under that LAW .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed , arguing , inter alia , that , in as much as it mentioned the grounds for his detention , the order was purporting to certify a fact .

CARDINAL . NORP On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal . It conceded that the reasons for the detention order certified a fact . However , the order referred to a letter by the head of the GPE militia , and that was the only thing which it certified . Therefore , a declaration that the order was incorrect would be of no benefit to the applicant , because that letter would still prevent him from obtaining compensation under LAW . The court went on to say that a judicial declaration that the official who had drawn up the order had recorded a false statement of fact would have no direct effect on the applicant ’s legal sphere .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed , arguing , inter alia , that his legal interest in obtaining a declaration that the detention order was incorrect was based on his right , enshrined in LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and LAW , to protect his private life against false and defamatory information . He argued that his case was identical to LAW ( [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL , ORG CARDINALV ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( NORP касационен съд ) upheld the lower court ’s decision ( опр. № CARDINAL от DATE г. по гр. ч. д. № CARDINAL г. , ORG , GPE г. о. ) . It held that the detention order could not presently be challenged as to the authenticity of its reasoning . Such a challenge had been possible only at the time when the order had been made , by appealing against the sanction that it had imposed . Inasmuch as the applicant sought to nullify the order ’s effects , he could do so in the manner prescribed by LAW . That was the proper way of vindicating his reputation and honour .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested that the social security services supplement his pension on the basis of section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act ( see paragraph CARDINAL in fine below ) . On DATE they turned down the request , reasoning , on the basis of the result of the DATE proceedings and the DATE certificate ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL above ) , that there was no indication that the repression against the applicant had been political . It does not seem that the applicant appealed against or sought judicial review of that decision .

CARDINAL . On DATE , DATE , the applicant asked the regional governor of GPE to pay him compensation under sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the DATE LAW see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) , in respect of his detention in DATE . On DATE the governor turned down the request , saying that the certificate issued by ORG in DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) showed that the applicant had not been detained on grounds falling within the ambit of the CARDINAL Act . He was therefore not entitled to compensation . It does not seem that the applicant sought judicial review of the governor ’s decision .

CARDINAL . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE the special commission set up under section CARDINAL ) of the CARDINAL Act ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) advised the applicant that , according to section ORG ) of the LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , it could act only on the basis of referrals by regional governors or the social security authorities , not on the basis of requests by individuals .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date ORG handed all documents concerning the applicant ’s detention in DATE to the commission set up under LAW on access to documents revealing the collaboration of NORP citizens with the former ORG security and the former intelligence agencies of ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . On DATE the commission sent copies of those documents to ORG .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of the DATE LAW read as follows :

“ The private life of citizens shall be inviolable . All citizens are entitled to be protected against unlawful interference with their private or family life and against infringements of their honour , dignity and reputation . ”

“ Everyone has the right to seek , receive and impart information . The exercise of that right may not be directed against the rights and the good name of other citizens or against national security , public order , public health or morals . ”

CARDINAL . The Political and Civic Rehabilitation of Persecuted Individuals Act ( DATE ) ( ORG за политическа и гражданска реабилитация на репресирани лица ) was adopted for the purpose of providing redress to persons subjected to repression during the communist regime on account of their origin , political views or religious convictions ( section CARDINAL ) . CARDINAL of the forms of repression covered by the LAW is detention in labour communities , camps or similar places ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ( former CARDINAL ) ) , those so detained can apply for a oneoff sum by way of compensation in respect of any pecuniary or nonpecuniary damage sustained . If they die before receiving compensation in respect of pecuniary damage sustained , it is to be paid to their surviving children , parents or siblings ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . In DATE a new section CARDINAL was added , providing that persons subjected to repressions could also request a supplement to their pensions .

CARDINAL . Initially the request for a oneoff payment of compensation was to be made to ORG ( section CARDINAL ) , as in force until DATE ) . In DATE that competence was transferred to the governor of the region where the person lives ( section CARDINAL ) , as in force since DATE ) . The governor must rule on the request after gathering evidence about the type , severity and duration of the repression , as well as about the applicant ’s entitlement to compensation ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . He has to request applicants to present written evidence in support of their claims ( section CARDINAL ) ) . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , added in DATE , provides that if there is no written evidence about the type , character or duration of the repression , the governor must of his own motion obtain a ruling by a special factfinding commission ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . According to the wellestablished case - law of ORG , the governor ’s failure to do so is a serious breach of the rules of administrative procedure and constitutes grounds to invalidate his or her decision and refer the matter back to him or her with instructions to make a referral to the commission ( реш. № DATE от CARDINAL май DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. , PERSON , ORG ; реш. № DATE от CARDINAL септември DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. , PERSON , петчленен състав ; реш. № CARDINAL от CARDINAL март DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. , PERSON , ORG ; реш. № DATE от DATE г. по адм. д. № CARDINAL/CARDINAL г. , PERSON , ORG ; реш. № DATE от CARDINAL юни DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. , PERSON , ORG ; реш. № CARDINAL от CARDINAL декември DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. , PERSON , ORG ; реш. № DATE от CARDINAL май DATE г. по адм. д. № CARDINAL/ DATE г. , PERSON , ORG ; реш. № DATE от CARDINAL юли DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. , ORG , ORG ; реш. № CARDINAL от CARDINAL януари DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. , ORG , ORG ) . The governor ’s refusal to grant compensation is subject to judicial review ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . The request for a pension supplement must be made to the social security authorities ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . They have to follow the same evidencegathering rules as the regional governors ( section CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) ) . Their failure to obtain a ruling by the special commission in the event of a lack of written evidence is a serious breach of the rules of administrative procedure and constitutes grounds to invalidate their decisions and refer the matter back to them with instructions to make a referral to the commission ( реш. № DATE от CARDINAL юни DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. , ORG ; реш. № CARDINAL от CARDINAL януари DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. , ORG ; реш. № CARDINAL от CARDINAL май DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. , ORG ; реш. № DATE от CARDINAL октомври DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. , ORG ) .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL ) , if there is no written evidence about the nature and the character of the alleged repression , the relevant facts are to be established by a special commission to be set up under regulations adopted by ORG . In unclear cases the commission has to determine the political – or not – character of the repression by a simple majority vote ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . To assist that determination , all authorities must provide the commission with the relevant documents in their possession ( ibid . ) .

CARDINAL . NORP The commission ’s work is governed by regulations issued by ORG . Such regulations ( ORG за прилагане на чл. CARDINAL от Закона за политическа и гражданска реабилитация на репресирани лица ) were first adopted in DATE , setting up both a central commission and regional commissions subordinate to it ( regulation CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . Regulation CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provided that those concerned could make applications for the establishment of past repressions to the regional commissions . All sorts of evidence , including witness statements , were allowed ( regulation CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . The regional commission had to rule by means of a reasoned decision ( regulation CARDINAL ) ) , which could be challenged before the central commission ( regulation CARDINAL ) ) . The central commission could uphold the decision , quash it , or determine the point de novo , and could gather evidence ( regulation CARDINAL ) ) . Its decision also had to be reasoned ( regulation CARDINAL ) ) . It was not subject to judicial review ( regulation CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . Those regulations were repealed with effect from DATE .

CARDINAL . New regulations were adopted in DATE . The main change which they introduced was that there were no regional commissions , only a central one ( regulation CARDINAL ) . From the wording of regulation ORG ) it seems that the commission could act both on the basis of applications by the persons concerned and on referrals by the competent authorities . It could act if there was a complete or partial lack of written evidence of the repression , and that lack had been certified by the authorities supposed to hold such documents ( regulation CARDINAL ) ) . The rules of evidence and procedure were similar to those under LAW ( regulation CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) ) . The commission ’s decisions were not subject to judicial review ( regulation CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Those regulations were in turn superseded by new regulations adopted in DATE ; those are still in force . LAW ) provides that the commission acts on the basis of the applications by those concerned . It can act if there is a complete or partial lack of written evidence of the repression , and if that lack has been certified by the authorities supposed to hold such documents ( ibid . ) . It can also act on the basis of referrals by the competent authorities ( regulation ORG ) ) . The rules of evidence are the same as in the previous regulations ( regulation CARDINAL ) ) . The commission ’s decisions are not subject to judicial review ( regulation CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Access to the documents of the DATE ORG security agencies has been the subject of fierce debate in NORP society ever since the regime ’s demise in DATE . DATE , the matter was raised in ORG CARDINAL times , with no results .

CARDINAL . On DATE the legislature enacted the Act on access to documents of the former ORG security agencies and the former ORG of ORG ( ORG за достъп до документите на бившата Държавна сигурност и бившето ORG управление на GPE щаб ) . The LAW created a special commission whose chief task was to gather information about and make public the names of individuals who had collaborated with the communistera security services ( section CARDINAL ) . The commission ’s first meeting took place on DATE . In addition , under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , any NORP citizen could ask the commission to check whether information had been gathered about him by those services . He or she could then access the information ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) , and request that documents or parts of documents be made secret if they contained “ personal or family secrets ” ( section CARDINAL ) . “ Personal or family secrets ” meant information which was not of a public nature and pertained to the persons concerned or their relatives in the direct line or their spouses ( paragraph CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the Act ’s transitional and concluding provisions ) . Classification requests could be turned down if , inter alia , the documents contained information about violence towards others ( section CARDINALa(CARDINAL ) in limine ) . Section PERSON ) specifically prohibited the destruction of originals or the only remaining copies of documents created by the former security services .

CARDINAL . A group of members of ORG challenged the LAW in its entirety before ORG . In a decision of DATE , to which were appended CARDINAL separate opinions ( реш. № CARDINAL от CARDINAL септември DATE г. по к. д. № CARDINAL/CARDINAL г. , обн. , GPE , бр. CARDINAL от CARDINAL октомври DATE г. ) , that court allowed the challenge in respect of CARDINAL provisions relating to the publication of the names of individuals who had been affiliated with the communistera security services , but did not touch any of the abovementioned dataaccess provisions .

CARDINAL . A DATE amendment to the LAW was likewise challenged in its entirety before ORG . In a decision of DATE , to which were appended CARDINAL separate opinions ( реш. № CARDINAL от DATE г. по к. д. № CARDINAL/CARDINAL г. , обн. , GPE , бр. CARDINAL от DATE г. ) that court allowed the challenge in respect of CARDINAL provision which was unrelated to the dataaccess provisions .

CARDINAL . The Act was repealed in DATE with the enactment of ORG ( DATE ) ( ORG за защита на класифицираната информация ) . On DATE a group of members of parliament challenged the repealing provision , paragraph CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of that Act ’s transitional and concluding provisions , before ORG as being contrary to , inter alia , LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . ORG could not reach a majority , an equal number of judges having voted in favour of the challenge and against it , and , in accordance with its practice that in such situations the request for a statutory provision to be struck down is considered as dismissed by default , rejected the challenge ( реш. № CARDINAL от DATE г. по к. д. № CARDINAL/CARDINAL г. , обн. , GPE , бр. CARDINAL от CARDINAL октомври DATE г. ) .

CARDINAL . To fill , at least partly , the gap left by the repeal of the LAW , on DATE the Minister of the ORG issued an Instruction governing the manner of accessing information held in the Ministry ’s archive ( Инструкция № ICARDINAL за реда за достъп до информация , съдържаща се в документите от архивните фондове на Министерството на вътрешните работи ) . It gave everyone the right to access information which was not classified ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) , even for research and journalistic purposes ( section CARDINAL ) , but provided that personal data could be accessed only by those to whom it related ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) specifically entitled everyone to access personal information which related to them or their close relatives . Information about third parties could be accessed only on the basis of a notarised authorisation signed by those third parties or their heirs ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . If a person wished to access documents containing information about others , such documents could be made available only after the personal information had been taken out ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) , unless those requesting access provided a notarised authorisation ( section DATE ) ) . ORG has justified restricting access to information CARDINAL parties on the basis of those provisions ( реш. № DATE от CARDINAL декември DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. , ORG , петчленен състав ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the legislature enacted the LAW on access to documents revealing the collaboration of NORP citizens with the former ORG security and the former intelligence agencies of ORG ( ORG за достъп и разкриване на документите и за обявяване на принадлежност на български граждани към Държавна сигурност и разузнавателните служби на Българската народна армия ) . It was based on CARDINAL separate bills , put forward by different political parties , which were merged . All CARDINAL of them referred to the need to reveal the truth about the activities of the communist regime ’s security apparatus and to comply with ORG Resolution CARDINAL ( DATE ) “ on measures to dismantle the heritage of former communist totalitarian systems ” ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . The Act came into force on DATE and is still in force . It created a special commission whose main task is to gather information about and make public the names of individuals who collaborated with the communistera security services and who occupied or continue to occupy public posts ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) ) . The commission ’s members were elected by ORG on DATE . The commission ’s other task is to provide individuals or their close relatives access to information which the former security services have gathered about them ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) , and to organise access to the documents contained in those services’ archives , which had to be handed over to it within DATE after the LAW came into force ( paragraph CARDINAL of the Act ’s transitional and concluding provisions ) . However , that did not happen within the prescribed timeframe , partly because the commission did not have anywhere to store the archives . On DATE ORG decided to provide a building in which to house them . It seems that the documents then started to be gradually handed over to the commission by the various authorities previously in charge of them . It seems that this process is still continuing . Those documents were to be stored in a centralised archive managed by the commission ( sections CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL ) . Under paragraph CARDINAL of the Act ’s transitional and concluding provisions , the commission also took over the archives of the commission set up under LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . After the commission completes its task , all its materials are to be stored in accordance with ORG ( DATE ) ( paragraph CARDINAL of the Act ’s transitional and concluding provisions ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) provides that any person has the right to access information gathered by the former security agencies about him or about deceased relatives of his in the direct line , including the second degree of kinship . Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) , any person has the right to access the documents contained in the archive of those agencies for scientific , journalistic or research purposes , under the conditions and in line with the procedure laid down in ORG ( DATE ) ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . Access means the right to read the documents and receive copies of them ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) ) . Where the contents of the documents may seriously infringe the rights of individuals whose names are mentioned in them , and those individuals or their heirs have not given their express written consent , the sensitive data must be taken out of the copies given to the persons requesting access ( section ORG ) ) . They also have to sign a nondisclosure declaration ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of ORG ( DATE ) ( ORG за защита на личните данни ) provides that the LAW does not apply to information contained in the national archives . It is , however , unclear whether it applies to information contained in the archive managed by the commission set up under LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of ORG ( DATE ) ( ORG за достъп до обществена информация ) , an authority which has received a request for access to information which relates to a private person must seek that person ’s express written consent . If that person gives such consent under certain conditions , the authority is bound to restrict access to the information in line with those conditions ( ibid . ) . If that person does not give consent , the authority must provide access to the information in a way that does not reveal the bits of information relating to that person ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . A lack of consent amounts to grounds for refusing access to the information ( section CARDINAL ) ) . Consent is not necessary if there is an overriding public interest in the information being revealed ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . The authority ’s decision to give or refuse access to information is subject to judicial review ( sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the DATE Code of Civil Procedure , superseded by LAW , provided that claims for judicial declarations that legally relevant facts ( as opposed to legal relations ) exist or do not exist could be brought only where specifically provided for by law .

CARDINAL . The new Article CARDINALb § CARDINAL of the DATE LAW , added pursuant to paragraph CARDINAL ) of the transitional and concluding provisions of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , makes it an offence to destroy , conceal , forge or damage a document created by the communistera State security agencies .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG adopted LAW ( DATE ) “ on measures to dismantle the heritage of former communist totalitarian systems ” . It reads , in so far as relevant :

“ ... CARDINAL . The ORG recommends that the prosecution of individual crimes go handinhand with the rehabilitation of people convicted of ‘ GPE which in a civilised society do not constitute criminal acts , and of those who were unjustly sentenced . Material compensation should also be awarded to these victims of totalitarian justice , and should not be ( much ) lower than the compensation accorded to those unjustly sentenced for crimes under the standard penal code in force .

CARDINAL . The ORG welcomes the opening of secret service files for public examination in some former NORP totalitarian countries . It advises all countries concerned to enable the persons affected to examine , upon their request , the files kept on them by the former secret services . ... ”
